<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
```c
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
static bool irq_handling_stop
...
static pthread_t irq_pthread
...
static int irq_notify_fd
...
static metal_mutex_t irq_lock
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL) passes irq_pthread by value (pthread_t is passed by value) and the second parameter is NULL, so no function parameter of the caller is modified. pthread_join may store a thread return via the void **retval, but that would modify the pointed-to object, not the pointer itself; in this call no pointer is provided. Therefore MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is not violated.
